environment.description: Fork, clone and install dependencies to start developing.

environment.install: Install dependencies and start the development server:

faq.q1: How do I fork on GitHub?
faq.a1: Go to the original repository, click 'Fork' at the top of the page. This creates a copy in your profile. Then clone from YOUR repository (github.com/YOUR-USER/dev-showcase).
faq.q2: What Node.js version do I need?
faq.a2: Node.js 18+ is required. We recommend using nvm to manage versions. Check with node --version.
faq.q3: Can I use npm or yarn?
faq.a3: The project uses pnpm as the package manager. Install it with npm install -g pnpm.
faq.a4: It's the integration branch. Every new feature branches from it and every PR merges back to it before going to main.
faq.q5: pnpm install gave an error, what to do?
faq.a5: Make sure you're using Node.js 18+ and pnpm 8+. Try deleting node_modules and pnpm-lock.yaml, then run pnpm install again.

structure.title: Understanding the structure
structure.description: Learn the main folders and where each type of code lives.
structure.intro: Click on folders to explore the project structure:

tree.app: Next.js routes (App Router) — each folder = a URL
tree.ui: UI primitives: Button, Card, Badge, Input, Tabs...
tree.features: Business domains — each feature in its own folder
tree.data: Static data and content registries for the project
tree.contentTs: Registry of all dynamic pages (guides, implementations, tools)
tree.changelogTs: Version history and changes — powers the /novidades page
tree.novidades: Changelog page — lists all versions and improvements
tree.dynamicHelper: Dynamic page system — connects slugs to components
tree.messages: Translation files by language (pt-BR, en, es, de)

faq.q1: Where do I create my component?
faq.a1: If reusable (e.g. button, card), in src/components/. If feature-specific, in src/features/feature-name/.
faq.a2: Each business domain has its folder. E.g. contribute/, implementations/, guides/. Specific components, hooks and data go there.
faq.a3: We use Tailwind CSS directly in components. Global styles are in src/app/globals.css.
faq.a4: content.ts is the central registry of all content pages (guides, implementations, tools). dynamic-page-helper.tsx connects each slug to the actual component via lazy loading. Together, they make the page appear automatically at the right URL.
faq.q5: Do I need to create a folder for each new feature?
faq.a5: Yes! Follow the pattern: src/features/guides/my-feature/ for guides, src/features/implementations/my-feature/ for implementations. The main file is always index.tsx.

creating.title: Creating the feature
creating.description: Create the main component. The project has two paths: dynamic pages (guides/implementations) and standalone.
creating.descriptionImprove: Locate the code you need to change in the project.

newFeature.choiceTitle: What type of page do you want to create?
newFeature.choiceDesc: The project has two paths: dynamic pages (that appear in /dicas, /implementacoes or /ferramentas automatically) and standalone pages (like /contribua sections). Choose the right path for your feature.
newFeature.dynamicDesc: Dynamic pages are automatically routed via slug. You only need to create the component — the route already exists at /dicas/[slug], /implementacoes/[slug] or /ferramentas/[slug].
newFeature.dynamicNote: Dynamic pages do NOT need their own page.tsx or loading.tsx — the dynamic [slug]/page.tsx route already exists. The next step (Registration) shows how to connect your component to the system.
newFeature.standaloneDesc: For pages outside the dynamic system (e.g. /contribua sections), you need to create the route manually:

improve.searchTip: Use global search (Ctrl+K) or grep to locate the file. The folder structure follows this pattern:

faq.a1: Use Server Component by default (no 'use client'). Add 'use client' only if you need hooks, events or browser state.
faq.q2: Which path to choose: dynamic or standalone?
faq.a2: If it's a guide, implementation or tool, use the dynamic system — it's simpler and standardized. Use standalone only for special sections like /contribua.
faq.q3: Do I need to create page.tsx for dynamic pages?
faq.a3: No! The [slug]/page.tsx routes already exist for each category. Just create the component and register it in the next step.

registration.title: Registration & Integration
registration.description: Connect your component to the project's routing, search and navigation systems.
registration.descriptionImprove: Verify that existing integrations continue working after your changes.
registration.dynamicIntroDesc: The project uses a centralized system: the component is registered once and automatically gets routing, SEO, search and listing.
registration.contentTsDesc: Add your content to the CONTENT_ITEMS array. The slug becomes the URL, the category defines which section it appears in.
registration.componentMapDesc: Connect the component name (string from content.ts) to the actual dynamic import. Use lazy loading with next/dynamic.
registration.searchIntegrationDesc: For your page to appear in global search (Ctrl+K), do both steps below. Otherwise, anyone using the site search won't find your page.
registration.searchHowItWorks: How it works: the system builds results from content.ts; title and description come from search.json (one per locale); keywords come from tagMap. That's why both files are required.
registration.searchRequired: Without search.json and tagMap, the page won't show in search results.
registration.searchChecklist1: search.json filled in all 4 locales (pt-BR, en, es, de) with items.'{slug'}'.title and .description
registration.searchChecklist2: tagMap in search-data.ts with your slug and tags (words users would type when searching)
registration.searchChecklist3: Test: open search (Ctrl+K) and type the page title or one of its tags
registration.searchChecklist4: Test: open the search (Ctrl+K) and enter the title or a tag from your page.
registration.listingPageDesc: Each listing page (/dicas, /implementacoes) uses an iconMap to display icons. Add the slug and a Lucide icon.
registration.improveIntro: When improving existing code, verify these integrations still work:

improveChecklist.r1: Global search (Ctrl+K) finds the page normally
improveChecklist.r2: Category listing displays the page with correct icon
improveChecklist.r4: search.json translations are updated in all 4 languages
improveChecklist.r5: Build (pnpm build) passes without type errors
improveChecklist.r6: Build (pnpm build) passes without type errors

faq.q1: What happens if I forget COMPONENT_MAP?
faq.a1: The page will return 404. COMPONENT_MAP is the link between the slug (URL) and the actual component. Without it, the system doesn't know which component to render.
faq.q2: Do I need to add to nav (navigation menu)?
faq.a2: Not required. The navigation menu shows only featured items configured in nav-data.ts. Your page will already appear in the listing and search.
faq.a3: The system generates metadata (title, description, Open Graph) automatically using search.json translations and the buildPageMetadata function. The URL is generated from the slug and category.
faq.q4: How do I test if the registration worked?
faq.a4: Run pnpm dev and visit your page URL (e.g. /dicas/graphql-tips). Also test global search (Ctrl+K) and the category listing. If you get 404, check COMPONENT_MAP and content.ts.
faq.a5: Standalone pages don't use content.ts or COMPONENT_MAP. But they still need an entry in search-data.ts (STANDALONE_PAGES array) and search.json translations to appear in global search.
faq.q6: I forgot to add search.json or tagMap. What happens?
faq.a6: The page is still reachable by URL and from the listing (/dicas, /implementacoes), but it won't show when someone uses global search (Ctrl+K). Just add items.'{slug'}' to all 4 search.json files and the slug to tagMap in search-data.ts.

developing.title: Developing
developing.description: Code patterns, available components and project best practices.

patterns.p1: Strict TypeScript — no any, explicit types
patterns.p2: Functional components with arrow functions or function declarations
patterns.p4: All visible text uses i18n (next-intl) — never hardcode
patterns.p5: Accessibility: aria-labels, semantic roles, keyboard navigation

developing.componentsDesc: Reuse Design System components. Check the full catalog at /contribua/design-system.

faq.a1: Yes, but sparingly. Prefer libs already used in the project. Add via pnpm add package-name.
faq.a2: Wrap your content with the AnimatedSection component (e.g. delay 0.1). For more complex animations, use framer-motion directly.
faq.q3: Where can I see available components?
faq.a3: Visit /contribua/design-system for the full catalog with interactive previews and code for each component.

i18n.title: Translations (i18n)
i18n.description: All visible text must be translated. pt-BR is the source of truth.

workflow.w2: Register the namespace in messages/pt-BR/index.ts (and other languages) and in src/lib/i18n/load-messages.ts (NAMESPACES array)
workflow.w4: Add title and description in messages/*/search.json (for global search)
workflow.w5: If added to nav, update messages/*/nav.json with label and description
workflow.w6: Create files for the other 3 languages (en, es, de) or use pnpm translate

i18n.tip: The pnpm translate script can help generate automatic translations via DeepL for other languages.

faq.q1: Can I contribute only in pt-BR?
faq.a1: Yes! Create the keys in pt-BR and use the translation script or ask for help in the PR for other languages.
faq.a2: It's the name of the translation JSON file. Each page/feature has its own (e.g. tutorialPage, contributePage).
faq.q3: How do I use translations in Server Components?
faq.a3: Use getTranslations('namespace') from next-intl/server instead of useTranslations.

a11y.title: Accessibility
a11y.description: Ensuring everyone can use the platform is a priority.

checklist.c3: Navigation works 100% via keyboard (Tab, Enter, Escape)
checklist.c4: Color contrast meets WCAG AA (4.5:1 for text)
checklist.c5: Heading structure is hierarchical (h1 → h2 → h3)
checklist.c8: Dynamic content uses aria-live or role='status'

faq.a1: Accessible Rich Internet Applications — HTML attributes that add semantic meaning for screen readers.
faq.a2: Navigate using only keyboard (Tab/Enter). Use the axe DevTools extension in Chrome. Test with a screen reader if possible.
faq.q3: Do I need to add skip links?
faq.a3: The project already has global skip links. But if you create a page with lots of navigation, consider adding them.

quality.title: Quality
quality.description: Lint, tests and build must pass before opening the PR.
quality.build: Full build — validates TypeScript and SSR
quality.allGreen: All must pass without errors before the PR.

faq.a1: Run pnpm lint --fix to auto-fix. Type errors (TypeScript) need to be fixed manually.
faq.q2: Do I need to add tests?
faq.a2: Recommended but not mandatory for every contribution. If you add complex logic, a test is welcome.
faq.q3: Build gave a type error, what to do?
faq.a3: Check that all imports are correct and types are consistent. The error usually points to the exact line and file.
faq.q4: A test failed on something I didn't change, what to do?
faq.a4: This can happen if a test depended on something that changed indirectly. Run pnpm test -- --verbose for details. If it's not your change, mention it in the PR.
faq.q5: Do I need to run all 3 commands every time?
faq.a5: Yes! Before opening the PR, lint + test + build must pass. CI (GitHub Actions) will run these same checks automatically.

pr.title: Pull Request
pr.description: Time to submit your contribution for review!

commits.fix: fix: correct translation key for navbar
commits.docs: docs: update README with setup instructions

prItems.i2: Description of what was done and why
prItems.i3: Screenshots if there are visual changes

pr.done: Congratulations! Your contribution is on its way. After review, your code goes live on the platform.

faq.a1: type(scope): description — E.g. feat(tutorial): add interactive file tree. Types: feat, fix, docs, style, refactor, test, chore.
faq.a2: The project maintainers. They may request changes — that's normal and part of the process!
faq.q3: Can I make multiple commits in the PR?
faq.a3: Yes! Multiple organized commits are welcome. Keep each commit focused on a single change.
faq.q4: What if my PR has conflicts?
faq.a4: Update your branch with develop: git checkout develop && git pull && git checkout your-branch && git merge develop. Resolve conflicts in the marked files and make a new commit.
faq.a5: Depends on complexity, but usually 1-3 days. Keep the PR small and focused for faster reviews. PRs with more than 500 lines take longer.
